note: SetText nodes for GCSE English Literature. AQA specification used as primary reference (70%+ market share). Each text that appears on multiple boards gets one node per board. This initial file covers the most widely taught AQA set texts. Edexcel, OCR, Eduqas nodes can be added as separate entries when needed. Popularity estimates from teacher surveys and exam entry data 2019-2025.

set_texts.name: Macbeth
set_texts.title: The Tragedy of Macbeth
set_texts.author: William Shakespeare
key_context_points: Jacobean attitudes to witchcraft and King James I's Daemonologie (1597)
The Gunpowder Plot (1605) and anxiety about regicide
The Great Chain of Being and divine right of kings
The real Macbeth (11th-century Scottish king)
Patriarchal gender roles in Jacobean society
The role of the theatre as moral instruction

key_quotations.speaker: Lady Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: unsex me here
key_quotations.significance: Transgression of gender roles, invocation of supernatural power to reject femininity

key_quotations.speaker: Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: I have no spur / To prick the sides of my intent, but only / Vaulting ambition
key_quotations.significance: Admits ambition is his sole motivation; horse metaphor suggests overreaching that will result in a fall

key_quotations.speaker: Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood / Clean from my hand?
key_quotations.significance: Guilt overwhelms immediately after the murder; hyperbolic imagery of permanent stain contrasts with Lady Macbeth's dismissiveness

key_quotations.speaker: Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: It will have blood, they say: blood will have blood
key_quotations.significance: Proverbial language suggests Macbeth recognises the inevitability of retribution; cyclical violence

key_quotations.speaker: Lady Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: Out, damned spot!
key_quotations.significance: Role reversal — Lady Macbeth now overwhelmed by guilt she earlier dismissed; imagined blood stain mirrors Macbeth's Act 2 Neptune speech

key_quotations.speaker: Macbeth
key_quotations.quotation: a tale / Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, / Signifying nothing
key_quotations.significance: Nihilistic despair and meta-theatrical commentary; life reduced to meaningless performance

set_texts.name: A Christmas Carol
set_texts.title: A Christmas Carol. In Prose. Being a Ghost Story of Christmas
set_texts.author: Charles Dickens
key_context_points: Victorian attitudes to poverty and the 'undeserving poor'
The 1834 Poor Law Amendment Act and workhouses
Malthusian economics and 'surplus population'
Dickens' own childhood experience of poverty and the blacking factory
The Victorian Christmas tradition and Dickens' role in popularising it
Child labour and education in Victorian England

key_quotations.speaker: Narrator
key_quotations.quotation: Oh! But he was a tight-fisted hand at the grindstone, Scrooge!
key_quotations.significance: Dickens establishes Scrooge as a caricature of miserliness; exclamatory address draws the reader into moral judgement

key_quotations.speaker: Scrooge
key_quotations.quotation: Are there no prisons? Are there no workhouses?
key_quotations.significance: Echoes real Victorian attitudes; Scrooge's questions will be answered and condemned by the narrative

key_quotations.speaker: Narrator (describing Ignorance and Want)
key_quotations.quotation: This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want. Beware them both
key_quotations.significance: Allegorical personification of social problems; Dickens' direct address to the Victorian reader

key_quotations.speaker: Scrooge
key_quotations.quotation: I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year
key_quotations.significance: Transformation complete; Christmas as metaphor for social responsibility, not seasonal charity

set_texts.name: Jekyll and Hyde
set_texts.title: Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
set_texts.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
key_context_points: Victorian respectability and the public/private divide
Darwinism and degeneration theory
The Carew murder case and Jack the Ripper (1888, two years later)
Scientific progress and ethical limits
Edinburgh's Old Town/New Town as geographical duality
Stevenson's Calvinist upbringing and concepts of predestination

key_quotations.speaker: Enfield
key_quotations.quotation: It wasn't like a man; it was like some damned Juggernaut
key_quotations.significance: Hyde described through negation — what he is NOT — suggesting something beyond human categorisation

key_quotations.speaker: Utterson
key_quotations.quotation: If he be Mr Hyde, I shall be Mr Seek
key_quotations.significance: Wordplay signals the detective-story structure; Utterson as rational investigator unable to comprehend the irrational

key_quotations.speaker: Jekyll
key_quotations.quotation: man is not truly one, but truly two
key_quotations.significance: Jekyll's central thesis; the novella's argument about human duality expressed in pseudo-scientific language

set_texts.name: An Inspector Calls
set_texts.title: An Inspector Calls
set_texts.author: J.B. Priestley
key_context_points: 1912 setting: Edwardian prosperity, class system, women's suffrage movement
1945 writing: post-war desire for social reform, Beveridge Report, welfare state
Priestley's socialist politics and wartime Postscripts broadcasts
The sinking of the Titanic (April 1912) as symbol of hubris
Workers' rights and trade unions in early 20th century
Women's limited legal rights in 1912 (property, employment, voting)

key_quotations.speaker: Birling
key_quotations.quotation: The Titanic — she sails next week... absolutely unsinkable
key_quotations.significance: Dramatic irony established immediately; Birling's confident predictions about the future are all wrong

key_quotations.speaker: Birling
key_quotations.quotation: a man has to mind his own business and look after himself and his own
key_quotations.significance: Birling's individualist philosophy — the antithesis of Priestley's socialist message — stated explicitly for the audience to reject

key_quotations.speaker: Inspector
key_quotations.quotation: We don't live alone. We are members of one body. We are responsible for each other
key_quotations.significance: The Inspector's final speech — Priestley's direct message to the audience; 'one body' echoes Christian and socialist language

key_quotations.speaker: Sheila
key_quotations.quotation: You're pretending everything's just as it was before
key_quotations.significance: Generational divide crystallised; Sheila represents the possibility of change that Priestley hopes for in the post-war generation

set_texts.name: Lord of the Flies
set_texts.title: Lord of the Flies
set_texts.author: William Golding
key_context_points: Written in response to WWII and the Holocaust — Golding's belief in innate human evil
Cold War anxieties about nuclear annihilation (the boys evacuated from a nuclear war)
Subversion of the Victorian boys' adventure story (Coral Island by R.M. Ballantyne)
Golding's experience as a WWII naval officer
Freudian psychology: id (Jack), ego (Ralph), superego (Piggy/Simon)

key_quotations.speaker: Ralph
key_quotations.quotation: This is our island. It's a good island
key_quotations.significance: Initial optimism and sense of adventure; Eden before the Fall

key_quotations.speaker: Simon
key_quotations.quotation: Maybe there is a beast... maybe it's only us
key_quotations.significance: Simon's prophetic insight — the beast is within human nature, not external

key_quotations.speaker: Lord of the Flies
key_quotations.quotation: You knew, didn't you? I'm part of you?
key_quotations.significance: The pig's head confirms Simon's thesis: evil is intrinsic, not external; hallucinatory scene as allegorical revelation

set_texts.name: Animal Farm
set_texts.title: Animal Farm: A Fairy Story
set_texts.author: George Orwell
key_context_points: Allegorical representation of the Russian Revolution and Stalinist Soviet Union
Napoleon = Stalin, Snowball = Trotsky, Old Major = Marx/Lenin
Orwell's democratic socialist politics and opposition to totalitarianism
Propaganda techniques and the manipulation of truth
The role of education and literacy in political control

key_quotations.speaker: Old Major
key_quotations.quotation: All animals are equal
key_quotations.significance: The founding principle of Animalism; its eventual corruption is the novella's central irony

key_quotations.speaker: Narrator
key_quotations.quotation: The pigs did not actually work, but directed and supervised the others
key_quotations.significance: The emergence of a new ruling class from the revolution's leadership — Orwell's warning about power

key_quotations.speaker: Pigs' commandment
key_quotations.quotation: All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others
key_quotations.significance: The final corruption of the original ideal; oxymoron captures the hypocrisy of totalitarian 'equality'

set_texts.name: Blood Brothers
set_texts.title: Blood Brothers
set_texts.author: Willy Russell
key_context_points: Liverpool in the 1960s-1980s: deindustrialisation, unemployment, class division
Thatcher-era politics: individualism, monetarism, north-south divide
Nature versus nurture debate: identical twins raised in different social classes
Russell's working-class Liverpool background and political commitment
The musical theatre form: songs as soliloquy, the Narrator as Greek chorus

key_quotations.speaker: Narrator
key_quotations.quotation: And do we blame superstition for what came to pass? / Or could it be what we, the English, have come to know as class?
key_quotations.significance: The play's central question stated directly; superstition as metaphor for systemic inequality

key_quotations.speaker: Mrs Johnstone
key_quotations.quotation: If we stay here we'll live for ever and ever
key_quotations.significance: Desperate optimism about the housing estate; ironic foreshadowing of the play's tragic ending

key_quotations.speaker: Mickey
key_quotations.quotation: I could have been him!
key_quotations.significance: Nature vs nurture crystallised; Mickey's rage at the arbitrary unfairness of class determines the tragedy

set_texts.name: Power and Conflict
set_texts.title: AQA GCSE Poetry Anthology: Power and Conflict
set_texts.author: Various (15 poets)
key_context_points: Romantic poetry and the sublime (Shelley, Wordsworth)
WWI poetry and the reality of trench warfare (Owen)
Post-colonial identity and cultural conflict (Agard, Dharker)
Northern Irish Troubles (Heaney)
Contemporary conflict and trauma (Garland, Weir)
The power of place and landscape in British poetry (Hughes, Wordsworth)

key_quotations.speaker: Shelley
key_quotations.quotation: Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
key_quotations.significance: Ironic — the works are ruined; transience of human power against time

key_quotations.speaker: Blake
key_quotations.quotation: In every cry of every Man, / In every Infant's cry of fear, / I hear the mind-forg'd manacles
key_quotations.significance: Psychological oppression — the chains are mental, imposed by institutions (church, state)

key_quotations.speaker: Owen
key_quotations.quotation: Our brains ache, in the merciless iced east winds that knive us
key_quotations.significance: Personified nature as the enemy; sibilance and physical discomfort establish suffering as the reality of war

key_quotations.speaker: Armitage
key_quotations.quotation: His blood-Loss shadow stays on the street
key_quotations.significance: Trauma persists after the event; the image literally 'remains'; PTSD encoded in the form

set_texts.name: Romeo and Juliet
set_texts.title: The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet
set_texts.author: William Shakespeare
key_context_points: Elizabethan attitudes to love and marriage (arranged marriages, patriarchal authority)
The Italian setting and English attitudes to Italy (passion, violence, Catholicism)
The Prologue's revelation of the ending: fate versus free will
Honour culture and the blood feud tradition
The role of women in Elizabethan society (obedience, marriage as economic transaction)

key_quotations.speaker: Chorus
key_quotations.quotation: A pair of star-cross'd lovers take their life
key_quotations.significance: Fate announced from the outset; the audience watches knowing the ending — every moment of hope is dramatic irony

key_quotations.speaker: Juliet
key_quotations.quotation: What's in a name? That which we call a rose / By any other name would smell as sweet
key_quotations.significance: Juliet challenges the arbitrary nature of names and social identity; identity versus social expectation

key_quotations.speaker: Romeo
key_quotations.quotation: O, I am fortune's fool!
key_quotations.significance: Structural turning point — Romeo recognises fate's control; the tragedy accelerates from this moment

set_texts.name: Frankenstein
set_texts.title: Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus
set_texts.author: Mary Shelley
key_context_points: Romantic era: the sublime, emotion, and imagination versus Enlightenment rationalism
Galvanism and early electrical experiments (Luigi Galvani, 1780s)
Mary Shelley's personal context: mother's death (Mary Wollstonecraft), elopement with Percy Shelley
The ghost story competition at Villa Diodati (1816)
Industrial Revolution and anxieties about scientific progress
Prometheus myth: the cost of stealing knowledge from the gods

key_quotations.speaker: Victor
key_quotations.quotation: I collected the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a spark of being into the lifeless thing
key_quotations.significance: The moment of creation described with deliberate vagueness; Victor never explains how, only that he did — the focus is on moral transgression, not method

key_quotations.speaker: Creature
key_quotations.quotation: I am malicious because I am miserable
key_quotations.significance: The Creature's argument for nurture over nature; evil as a product of social rejection, not inherent monstrosity

key_quotations.speaker: Victor
key_quotations.quotation: I was the true murderer
key_quotations.significance: Victor accepts moral responsibility; the creator is more monstrous than the creature
